title: Editorial Policy
text: Editorial Policy # editorial policy this site exists for **education and scholarship**. it is not a venue for political advocacy, admiration, or identity-based hostility. ## non‑glorification standard - no praise, hero narratives, or aestheticisation. - no “edgy” symbolism or design cues. - we avoid reproducing propaganda beyond what is necessary for analysis, and we provide context. ## evidence and sourcing - priority is given to **archives, peer‑reviewed research, and university‑press scholarship**. - every interpretive claim must be traceable to sources. - where evidence is incomplete, the uncertainty is stated plainly. ## disallowed content - hate speech, dehumanisation, or calls for violence. - holocaust denial, minimisation, or “just asking questions” rhetoric used to launder denial. - recruitment content, extremist messaging, or community-building for extremist politics. ## corrections and transparency - corrections are logged publicly. - disputed items are labelled as such, with citations representing mainstream scholarly treatments where available. if you wish to report an error, use the corrections page.

title: Methods: How to Read Evidence
text: Methods: How to Read Evidence # methods: how to read evidence this page is a practical guide to **provenance, reliability, and inference**. ## provenance checklist - what is the **origin** of the document (archive, collection, catalog number)? - is it an original, a copy, a postwar recollection, or a published excerpt? - are there **gaps** (missing pages, unclear dates, unknown chain of custody)? ## reliability notes reliability is not a moral judgement — it is an assessment of: - authentication, - author incentives and context, - consistency with corroborating materials, - editorial history. ## common pitfalls - treating absence of evidence as evidence of absence. - over-reading a single document without corroboration. - confusing postwar testimony with contemporaneous documentation. ## how this site labels uncertainty we use explicit labels: - **high confidence**: multiple independent corroborations. - **medium**: plausible but limited corroboration. - **low / contested**: weak provenance or significant dispute. see document card template in the primary sources index.

title: Primary Sources Index
text: Primary Sources Index # primary sources index this site uses **document cards**: structured entries that make sources citable and auditable. ## document card standard fields - date, author, recipient - document type (memo, minutes, directive, diary, etc.) - archive reference / publication reference - provenance and reliability notes - neutral takeaways (non-glorifying) - tags + hub links - scholarship notes (how historians use it) ## suggested citation practice use a consistent style (chicago, mla, etc.). include: - archive name + collection + call number - page/folio - editor/translator (if applicable) - stable url (if citing digitised materials) ## finding aids - how to locate digitised archive catalogues - how to request scans / reading room procedures - how to evaluate editions and translations (as you add real sources, you’ll expand this page with archive-by-archive guidance.)

title: Corrections & Updates
text: Corrections & Updates # corrections & updates this is a public log of corrections, clarifications, and updates. ## how to request a correction provide: - page url / document card id - what you believe is wrong - a citation or evidence trail supporting the correction ## update log - 2026-03-01 — site scaffold created; content is a template and will be expanded.

title: Template example: Cabinet/ministerial memo (structure demonstration)
text: template example: cabinet/ministerial memo (structure demonstration) this is a **template** document card showing how entries will be structured for auditability and citation. record the document’s purpose (administrative, military, propaganda, etc.) in neutral terms. note what the document explicitly states vs what is inferred. crosslink to related documents and to the hub page. template methods provenance sources historiography

title: Template example: Meeting minutes (structure demonstration)
text: template example: meeting minutes (structure demonstration) a second template card to demonstrate variety in document types and reliability notes. minutes often omit dissent; treat them as partial views of deliberation. check for follow-up documents: directives, implementation reports, correspondence. use tags to connect to governance, command, or propaganda hubs as appropriate. template minutes methods governance command sources
